subject: RE: [junit] Making Ant exec task failonerror if invoked suite has failures
msgSnippet: Are you executing the  tag?  We use: . . .
messageBody:
Are you executing the <fail> tag? We use:
.
.
.
<batchtest fork="on" failureProperty="tests-failed" toDir="${reportdir}/xml">
<fileset dir="${dir.build}">
<include name="${includeTestClasses}" />
<exclude name="${excludeTestClasses}" />
</fileset>
</batchtest>
</junit>
<fail message="Some of the tests failed" if="tests-failed" />

Any failing test in the batch sets the 'tests-failed' property and then the <fail> tag causes the Build Failed message to bubble up and out.

-----Original Message-----
From: Chad Woolley [mailto:lists@...]
Sent: Friday, October 31, 2003 2:37 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Making Ant exec task failonerror if invoked suite has failures


Hi,

In my project, I have to invoke the test suite indirectly through a batch/shell
script, using the Ant/Maven "exec" target in some scenarios.

The problem is that when I have test failures (not errors), the build shows
Successful even though I have failonerror=true for the exec target. In other
words, failures still return a good return code from java/exec. I can visually
see the failures print, but this doesn't work if I want to automate my builds
and failure reports.

What would be the best way to make failures cause the build to fail? Should I
catch the test failure in the tearDown() of each test, and throw a runtime
exception? Wouldn't this mask my failures when I run the tests through normal
means (single test through IDE, for example)?

Any ideas on how to resolve this?

Thanks,
Chad

P.S. If you are wondering why I have to use exec, this is because I am using a custom batch/shell script to set up the framework for the app. My app is an AOP test framework, and I am providing examples of using the AspectWerkz' "transparentbootclasspath" option under JDK 1.3: http://aspectwerkz.codehaus.org/online.html#Transparent%20bootclasspath
